metadata.description: Dictionary definitions for vocabulary words used in recommendation system

analysis.definition: The process of examining something in detail to understand its nature or to determine its essential features
examples: The scientist conducted a thorough analysis of the data.
Critical analysis is essential for understanding complex issues.

approach.definition: A way of dealing with something; a method or procedure
examples: The teacher used a new approach to teaching mathematics.
We need a systematic approach to solving this problem.

area.definition: A region or part of a town, a country, or the world
examples: This area of the city has many restaurants.
The park covers a large area.

assessment.definition: The act of judging or deciding the amount, value, quality, or importance of something
examples: The teacher gave a fair assessment of the student's work.
Environmental assessment is required before building projects.

assume.definition: To think or accept that something is true but without proof
examples: I assume you're coming to the meeting.
Don't assume that everyone agrees with you.

authority.definition: The power or right to give orders, make decisions, and enforce obedience
examples: The principal has authority over the school.
Local authorities are responsible for road maintenance.

available.definition: Able to be used or obtained; at someone's disposal
examples: The book is available at the library.
Tickets are available online.

benefit.definition: An advantage or profit gained from something
examples: Exercise has many health benefits.
The new policy will benefit all students.

challenge.definition: A difficult task or problem that tests someone's ability or determination
examples: Climbing Mount Everest is a major challenge.
The math problem presented a real challenge.

character.definition: The combination of qualities or features that distinguishes one person, group, or thing from another
examples: Honesty is an important character trait.
The story has many interesting characters.

communicate.definition: To share or exchange information, news, or ideas
examples: Students should learn to communicate effectively.
The scientist communicated her findings to the public.

compare.definition: To examine people or things to note similarities and differences
examples: Compare the two paintings and note their differences.
You cannot compare apples and oranges.

component.definition: One of several parts that together make up a whole
examples: The computer has many electronic components.
Teamwork is a key component of success.

consider.definition: To think carefully about something, especially when making a decision
examples: Please consider my proposal carefully.
We must consider all options before deciding.

construct.definition: To build or make something, especially something that is large or complicated
examples: Workers are constructing a new bridge.
The scientist constructed a hypothesis.

context.definition: The situation in which something happens and that helps you understand it
examples: You need to understand the historical context.
The word has a different meaning in this context.

contribute.definition: To give something, especially money or help, for a common purpose
examples: Everyone should contribute to the charity.
Hard work contributes to success.

coordinate.definition: To make different things work together effectively
examples: The coach coordinates the team's activities.
We need to coordinate our efforts.

core.definition: The central or most important part of something
examples: Reading is at the core of the curriculum.
The core of the earth is very hot.

create.definition: To make or invent something new
examples: Artists create beautiful paintings.
Scientists create new technologies.

culture.definition: The customs, arts, social institutions, and achievements of a particular nation, people, or other social group
examples: Learning about different cultures is important.
School culture affects student learning.

design.definition: To plan and make a drawing of how something will be made
examples: The architect designed a beautiful building.
Scientists design experiments.

detail.definition: A single fact or piece of information about something
examples: The report includes many important details.
Pay attention to the details.

develop.definition: To grow or cause to grow and become more mature, advanced, or elaborate
examples: Children develop physically and mentally.
The company is developing new products.

device.definition: An object or machine that has been invented for a particular purpose
examples: Smartphones are useful devices.
The scientist invented a new device.

document.definition: To record something in written form
examples: The researcher documented her observations.
Please document your sources.

dominant.definition: More important, powerful, or noticeable than others
examples: The dominant color in the painting is blue.
One political party is dominant in that country.

economy.definition: The system by which a country's money and goods are produced and used
examples: The economy is growing rapidly.
We need to be economical with our resources.

environment.definition: The conditions that affect the behavior and development of someone or something
examples: Protecting the environment is important.
School environment affects learning.

equipped.definition: Having the necessary tools or skills for a particular purpose
examples: The laboratory is well equipped.
Students are equipped with knowledge.

establish.definition: To start or create an organization, system, etc. that is meant to last for a long time
examples: The school was established in 1950.
Scientists establish theories.

evaluate.definition: To judge or calculate the quality, importance, amount, or value of something
examples: Teachers evaluate student work.
We need to evaluate the results.

evidence.definition: The available body of facts or information indicating whether a belief or proposition is true or valid
examples: There is strong evidence for climate change.
The detective found evidence at the crime scene.

factor.definition: One of several things that cause or influence something
examples: Weather is a factor in crop growth.
Many factors influence student success.

feature.definition: A distinctive attribute or aspect of something
examples: This phone has many useful features.
Geographic features include mountains and rivers.

focus.definition: To give attention to one particular person, thing, or situation
examples: The teacher focuses on student needs.
Please focus on your homework.

function.definition: The purpose for which something is designed or exists
examples: The function of the heart is to pump blood.
What is the function of this machine?

furthermore.definition: In addition to what has been said; moreover
examples: The test was difficult. Furthermore, we had little time.
Furthermore, the results were unexpected.

gender.definition: The state of being male or female
examples: Gender equality is important.
Some languages have gender-specific words.
Solar panels generate electricity.
The computer generates random numbers.

generation.definition: All the people who were born at approximately the same time
examples: The younger generation uses technology differently.
Each generation faces unique challenges.
People travel around the globe.
The globe is warming due to climate change.

goal.definition: The result or achievement toward which effort is directed
examples: Education is an important goal.
The team's goal is to win the championship.

grant.definition: To agree to give or allow something to someone
examples: The school granted permission for the field trip.
The foundation grants scholarships.

hierarchy.definition: A system in which people or things are placed in a series of levels with different importance or status
examples: School has a hierarchy of administrators.
Animal species form a hierarchy.

identify.definition: To recognize someone or something and say or prove who or what they are
examples: Can you identify this plant?
The scientist identified the new species.
The storm had a major impact on the city.
Social media has a big impact on society.

implement.definition: To put a plan, system, or agreement into action
examples: The school implemented a new curriculum.
We need to implement these changes.

individual.definition: A single person or thing, especially when compared to the group or set to which they belong
examples: Each individual has unique talents.
Respect individual differences.

influence.definition: The effect that a person or thing has on the way another person thinks or behaves
examples: Parents have a strong influence on children.
Social media influences public opinion.

infrastructure.definition: The basic systems and services that are needed for a country or organization to run smoothly
examples: The city needs better infrastructure.
Digital infrastructure supports modern education.

involved.definition: Being included in an activity or situation
examples: Many students are involved in sports.
The project involved complex calculations.

issue.definition: A subject or problem that people are thinking and talking about
examples: Climate change is an important issue.
The magazine issues monthly publications.
Farmers do hard physical labor.
Labor laws protect workers' rights.
Smoking is not legal in schools.
The lawyer gave legal advice.

legislation.definition: A law or set of laws suggested by a government and made official by a parliament
examples: New legislation protects the environment.
Congress passes legislation.

locate.definition: To find the exact position of something or someone
examples: Can you locate the library on the map?
The company will locate in the city center.

logical.definition: Reasonable and based on good judgment
examples: That is a logical conclusion.
Use logical thinking to solve problems.

maintain.definition: To keep something in good condition by checking or repairing it regularly
examples: Maintain good health through exercise.
The mechanic maintains the cars.
This is a major decision.
Math is his major subject.

method.definition: A particular way of doing something
examples: Scientists use the scientific method.
What method do you use to study?
The accident occurred yesterday.
Earthquakes occur along fault lines.
Ninety percent of students passed.
The battery is at 50 percent.
The Jurassic period lasted millions of years.
We have a study period after lunch.

policy.definition: A plan of action agreed or chosen by a government, business, etc.
examples: School policy prohibits bullying.
The company has a new privacy policy.

principle.definition: A fundamental truth or proposition that serves as the foundation for a system of belief
examples: Honesty is an important principle.
The principle of democracy is rule by the people.

procedure.definition: A way of doing something, especially the usual or correct way
examples: Follow the safety procedure.
What is the procedure for applying?

process.definition: A series of actions or steps taken in order to achieve a particular end
examples: The digestive process takes time.
Learning is a gradual process.

provide.definition: To make something available to someone
examples: Schools provide education.
The company provides health insurance.

range.definition: The area between limits within which something can operate or take place
examples: The mountain range is beautiful.
Temperatures range from hot to cold.

region.definition: A large area of land, usually with particular features
examples: The coastal region has mild weather.
Different regions have different customs.

relevant.definition: Connected with what is happening or being discussed
examples: That information is not relevant.
Choose relevant examples for your essay.

rely.definition: To depend on someone or something
examples: We rely on electricity for modern life.
You can rely on me to help.

remove.definition: To take something away from its place
examples: Remove the books from the shelf.
The stain was difficult to remove.

represent.definition: To act or speak officially for someone or something
examples: The ambassador represents her country.
This graph represents the data.

require.definition: To need something or make something necessary
examples: The job requires computer skills.
Plants require sunlight to grow.

research.definition: A detailed study of a subject, especially in order to discover new information
examples: Scientific research advances knowledge.
The student did research for her paper.

resource.definition: A useful or valuable possession or quality of a country, organization, or person
examples: Oil is an important natural resource.
The library is a valuable resource.

respond.definition: To react to something that has been said or done
examples: How did she respond to your question?
Plants respond to sunlight.

role.definition: The function or position that someone has in a situation or organization
examples: Teachers play an important role in education.
What is your role in the project?

section.definition: One of the parts that something is divided into
examples: The library has a fiction section.
This section of the test is difficult.

sector.definition: One of the areas into which the economic activity of a country is divided
examples: The technology sector is growing.
Agriculture is an important sector.

select.definition: To choose someone or something from a group
examples: Select your favorite color.
The committee selected three candidates.
This is a significant discovery.
There has been a significant improvement.

similar.definition: Looking or being almost the same as something else
examples: The two paintings are very similar.
Cats and dogs are similar in some ways.

source.definition: The place something comes from or starts at
examples: The river is the source of drinking water.
Cite your sources in research papers.

specific.definition: Clear and exact; particular and not general
examples: Give me specific instructions.
The recipe calls for specific ingredients.

structure.definition: The way in which the parts of something are connected together, arranged, or organized
examples: The structure of DNA is complex.
The building has a strong structure.

theory.definition: A formal statement of the rules on which a subject of study is based or of ideas that are suggested to explain a fact or event
examples: Einstein's theory of relativity.
Darwin's theory of evolution.
It rained, therefore the game was cancelled.
He studied hard, therefore he passed the test.
Though it was raining, we went outside.
She's smart, though sometimes quiet.

tradition.definition: A belief, custom, or way of doing something that has existed for a long time
examples: Family traditions are important.
Cultural traditions vary around the world.

transfer.definition: To move from one place to another
examples: Transfer the data to the new computer.
The player transferred to another team.

transport.definition: To take something or someone from one place to another
examples: Trucks transport goods across the country.
The bus transports students to school.

typical.definition: Showing the usual qualities or characteristics of a particular type of person, thing, or group
examples: This is typical winter weather.
What's typical behavior for this age group?

united.definition: Joined together, especially for a common purpose
examples: The United Nations works for peace.
The team is united in their goal.

university.definition: An institution of higher education and research
examples: Many students attend university after high school.
Harvard is a famous university.

variety.definition: The quality or state of being different or varied
examples: The store offers a variety of products.
Dietary variety is important for health.

version.definition: A particular form of something that differs in some respect from other forms of the same thing
examples: This is the latest version of the software.
There are different versions of the story.

volume.definition: The amount of space that a substance or object occupies
examples: The volume of water in the tank.
Speak at a louder volume.

welfare.definition: The health, happiness, and fortunes of a person or group
examples: The government provides welfare programs.
Animal welfare is important.
